node.contents: The reason is that the last line doesn't have a newline (yet). If you want to be able to deal with that, you'll need to a character at a time, and deal with the "prompt" appropriately.

astNode.text: The reason is that the last line doesn't have a newline (yet). If you want to be able to deal with that, you'll need to a character at a time, and deal with the "prompt" appropriately.

node.contents: @user496934 - if you have to deal with partial lines, you can't use `readLine()`. You have to read (and process) one character at a time using `read()`.

astNode.text: @user496934 - if you have to deal with partial lines, you can't use `readLine()`. You have to read (and process) one character at a time using `read()`.

node.contents: You are making the mistake of assuming that available() tells you how many bytes / characters are actually available. In fact, it tell you that at least that many are available ... and it might be wrong because it is an estimate.

astNode.text: You are making the mistake of assuming that available() tells you how many bytes / characters are actually available. In fact, it tell you that at least that many are available ... and it might be wrong because it is an estimate.

node.contents: Then you are compounding the problem by accessing the InputStream after you've wrapped it in a BufferedReader. So instead of getting the number of characters that can be read from the reader, you are getting the number of available bytes that haven't yet been read into the buffer yet.

astNode.text: Then you are compounding the problem by accessing the InputStream after you've wrapped it in a BufferedReader. So instead of getting the number of characters that can be read from the reader, you are getting the number of available bytes that haven't yet been read into the buffer yet.

node.contents: <hr />

astNode.text: <hr />

node.contents: You are probably better off simply reading from the BufferedReader a line at a time using readLine().

astNode.text: You are probably better off simply reading from the BufferedReader a line at a time using readLine().

node.contents: Use a loop to process all information and read till the end of the stream.

astNode.text: Use a loop to process all information and read till the end of the stream.

node.contents: Inputstream.available() does not do what you expected:

astNode.text: Inputstream.available() does not do what you expected:

node.contents: Returns an estimate of the number of bytes that can be read (or skipped over) from this input stream without blocking by the next invocation of a method for this input stream.

astNode.text: Returns an estimate of the number of bytes that can be read (or skipped over) from this input stream without blocking by the next invocation of a method for this input stream.
